article_title: Less may not mean more in lung cancer screenings
article_text:
Less may not mean more in lung cancer screenings Officials debate whether coverage will include cost of lung screenings for early detection of disease.

Sometimes less is more.

article_metadata.description: According to recent federal lung cancer statistics, only 15 percent of cases are typically found before the disease has spread.  By allowing for earlier detection through CT screening, research suggests that overall mortality from lung cancer can be reduced by as much as 20 percent.  [...] CMS should consider approving Medicare coverage for low-dose CT scans, but only if certain conditions are in place.  [...] CT scans should only be given to those with a long history of smoking.  [...] it's worth noting that many Americans at risk for lung cancer already have access to CT screening through private insurance plans whether Medicare patients receive it or not.  Because the Affordable Care Act will require all proven prevention methods to be reimbursed by ACA plans, those at-risk patients who purchased insurance through a state or federal exchange will soon receive the ability to have this screening reimbursed.
article_metadata.author.name: By Ernest Hawk, Therese Bevers  and Robert Volk
